comments.commentBody: that's the make america great again thing
If.
C) Both.

While Session's lies may not satisfy the men's rea required for reaching the legal definition of perjury, the United States simply can not tolerate an Attorney General that has lied to Congress. It's not even debatable. The glaring, insidious, fact that in these meetings none of Trump team members criticized or confronted the Russian ambassador over the well publicized DNC hackings, is a tacit indication of the inappropriate nature of the Russian contacts. The Trump-Russia connection has the Watergate feel. The daily stories in the Washington Post by Bob Woodward  and Carl Bernstein just wouldn't go away. The current day to day revelations of more contacts involving more members of the Trump administration are a mirror image of the Post stories.The shift from total denial of any meetings to grudging acknowledgement of each new tranche is an ominous portent.
Harder they come, harder they fall.

The One who has been doing the best reporting on this entire topic is Rachel Maddow. Quite frankly for the past few months That showcis never-miss, because of her excellent guests and way of building a developing story that shows myriad connections coming into clearer focus each week.

There's is a sharp divide now – no surprise now – between those who believe "something is going on" versus those who believe Democrats and some skeptical Republicans are gripped by Russia fever.

While I don't claim to know the big picture, I believe the experts do. From a Layman's perspective, I agree with former intelligence officer Malcolm Nance that all this smoke IS. The fire. I also believe Trump naïvely felt none of this would be discovered and that by now russian sanctions would be lifted.

Trump now seems hamstrung by his own sloppiness about Russia. And Putin must be livid that a man with so much promise could be so careless.

I believe there are indeed strong ties between Donald Trump and Russia. And most of the answers are buried in Trump's tax returns. I think He's deeply indebted to Russian oligarchs who parked their money in Trump properties to avoid expensive divorce costs or to keep it out of sight of Vladimir Putin, The chief accountant of Russian riches.

Finally I think many young reporters are going to cut their teeth on this entire sordid affair. This puzzle will be solved by the next Bernstein and Woodward, and for America sake, it can't come fast enough.
I'm guessing you mean Trump's impeachment can't come soon enough? The Dems invited the russian ambassador to the inauguration. What's going on here anyway?
Maddow's research brings extensive information to this discourse that I have not seen in the NYTimes. A good resource.

I agree totally with your assessment regarding Rachel Maddow's reporting.  Most interesting was her revelation last night regarding the ties between Dmitry Rybolovlev, the Russian fertilizer king, and Trump.  Dmitry apparently has been parking cash in Trump's lunch bucket for sometime.

Christopher Steele for president. Oh, he probably can't run because he isn't a citizen. But the Trumpeters could fake something and Steele isn't from Kenya. Or maybe he could be head of the CIA?

Steele is probably hiding deep, deep underground because he wouldn't last a minute in public .

Is there a person in the Trump administration who isn't a liar?

Great column Gail. You're always a laugh a minute but I'm finding it difficult to think this is amusing. I wonder what Don the Con was tweeting at 5 this A. M.?

So, the national question now is whether the Trump crowd consorted with the Russians to steal the election. Sort of makes the Republican's furor over Hillary's use of a private e-mail server for government business look downright silly. Not to mention the endless Benghazi thing that never went anywhere.
One wonders how many times sleazy Sessions would have perjured himself during a marathon interrogation like the one Trey Gowdy put Hillary through.
Of course it does, the trouble is, it looked that way for many months, and we elected the jerk president anyway.

For the politically incorrect who need space for undermining the Republic while making it great--for those who can't afford Mar-a-Largo or Trump International rates--and are looking for a quiet, non-descript guest or meeting place with easy access to I-95 and an airport, I offer my house, 50s cottage style, lots of sun, with a big great room.

Strictly off-the-books! No Airbnb record. Wide outdoors to yell politically incorrect rantings (we don't judge). Non-noisy neighbors. Both Mormon and Jehovah Witness evangelism. Morning walks with birds and very fat raccoons. Nearby black communities for photo-ops. (Only 35 minutes from Mother Emanuel AME Church.) A military base (Air Force), a military college (the Citadel), a religious college (Charleston Southern), lots of historic plantations (Middleton, Drayton Hall, Boone Hall) for galas, charming crafts (sweetgrass baskets!), and great varieties of African coffee (Ethiopian (3), Tanzanian, Rwandan) and infamous other side of the tracks. Farm-fresh greens.

It's a lovely backdrop for any spy meeting, even those that are not spy meetings, but want to give the appearance of being so, for the sake of angst and confusion. With working cell service and GPS, your every step can be tracked; your phones easily tapped. I promise to leak any documents or memos left under the bed.
The alternative to Cleveland!

Gail, this raises an interesting question: is it better to have an annoying person like Sen Cruz but you know what you are dealing with or to have an affable one like Sen Session whose behavior is contrary to his words and whose verbal gymnastic might be legal but not wholesome. Mr Session's response to Sen Franken's query about his relationship with the Russian ambassador is the moral equivalence of "I did not have sexual relationship with that nation!"
Walker is another GOP grifter - an operative for the rich- short on talent and long on lying. Why give him space in the NYT, he belongs in the Brietbart pages....

"It worked" (it actually didn't) in Wisconsin because of the unconstitutional gerrymandering of state legislative districts that engineered a Rep. legislative majority despite the Dem. electoral majority. https://www.nytimes.com/2016/11/21/us/wisconsin-redistricting-found-to-u...
http://www.politifact.com/wisconsin/statements/2012/dec/05/sandy-pasch/p...

Governor Walker is exactly right.

He took on the public employee unions the same way Reagan took on the striking air traffic controllers. With resolve and conviction.

Republican need to act unilaterally and fast. They need to railroad their agenda just like Obama railroaded the ACA.
So, what exactly is wrong with the ACA?

Regarding "more people in the state are working than ever," check this report:

"Turning in another subpar employment report, Wisconsin gained 29,616 private-sector jobs in the 12 months through September 2015, a 1.2% increase that lags behind the national pace of 2.2% in the same period, according to reliable data released Wednesday." -- Milwaukee Journal-Sentinel, 3/9/16

That hardly sounds like the success Mr. Walker portrays. His attempt to project his Wisconsin administration into a national campaign was rejected. Throughout 2016 he rated as one of the least popular governors in the nation -- hardly a program that has earned the support of his state's citizens. His presentation just doesn't fit the facts.

For the record, Mr. Trump won the election, but "the voters" chose Ms. Clinton. If you want to demonstrate "practical responsibility" to the voters who were "given a choice in November," you should enact the policies that she espoused.

Eric, enough with the paid protestor nonsense. You can't really believe that. People are alarmed about Trump and the GOP's agenda. Remember most voters voted against Trump. He does not have a mandate.
Well, Governor Walker, with a little more work you can turn Wisconsin into Kansas. As Kansans how well those policies have been working out there.
He already has. Just take a ride on the yellow brick roads of Wisconsin.

Scott Walker's heart is in an agenda which restricts workers' rights to bargain collectively and improve their position. His message here is, no matter how loudly or sincerely workers protest, ignore them. Regardless of how just their cause and true their opposition, resist negotiating with them. Don't bother finding common ground if it's part of your already conceived agenda.

With Walker "It's my way or the highway, I am right while you are wrong, so buzz off, worker." He could have made his point in one sentence: don't come to me with your complaints because my mind is made up.

Dear NYT,

You might want to check your fence, it appears there is a hole in the fence between you and camp delusional.

Gov Walker, aside from this self-serving piece I don't recall ever reading anything that identifies you taking "the high road." The manner in which you have treated working people in Wisconsin is anything but.

As for your assertions about the 2016 election and what the voters chose; Sec Clinton got almost 3,000,000 MORE votes than Trump. The only way republicans hold onto power is through gerrymandering, voter oppression, election irregularities via suspect, electronic voting machines, and the antiquated electoral college.

Your mean spirited approach to governing has harmed your state in measurable ways. Just like Kansas it is now an example of what not to do.
Dumb and dumber.

For people with serious chronic illnesses, no health insurance from an employer, and no spouse with such insurance, repealing Obamacare will be a death sentence.  So I hope that Governor Walker and his ilk will spare us more sloganeering about returning power to the states.  Repealing Obamacare is about cutting taxes for people who enjoy good health insurance, don't need Obamacare, and don't feel like paying for others' health care.  The only "principle" involved is greed.

The comments are sad coming from the person who is the architect of destroying the great state of Wisconsin. The fat cats control him and he does whatever they tell him to do. University of Wisconsin is a treasure of the Country and he is systematically destroying it as he has done with the other pillars of the State. Being a high school graduate, he does not believe in education because ignorance is a bliss for him. He manipulates the people by fake propaganda and fear mongering. Now he is worried that people are waking up and seeing the true color of the morally bankrupt Republican Party which survives on division, fear mongering, cheap rhetoric and the illusion of tax cuts. Mr. Walker is a master manipulator. Of course he should be worried. Your days of manipulation are coming to an end.

You know something, I do not at all consider anyone with the Republican label as a fellow citizen anymore. We don't share the same fundamental values, tastes or way of life. Now the United States is geographically divided into non-republican vs. republicans; that is, civilized vs. barbarian. Here's a proposal: we keep the coasts with its dynamism, innovation, wealth, ports open to Asia and Europe, and you keep the interior. I bet you'll be coming back to beg on your knees. Happy ranching.

Please include Illinois, which voted overwhelming for Clinton though this state is divided, like many others, between blue urban areas and red rural ones. Illinois, as it happens, is an example of a state in conflict because a Republican gov is standing so strong (like Walker, against unions) that we havent had a budget in 2.5 years, Chicago's been robbed of its $ for the public schools, social services throughout the state are getting cut and vendors going unpaid. Too bad financial whiz Rauner wont ask for a microtax on stock trades. Luckily he's facing election next year. And when is Walker being voted on again?

Dear Scott,

Nobody voted in November to hand over more power to the states. You and the Koch brothers should stop this nonsense propaganda to put more money into the hands of the 1/10 of the top 1% of the richest people in this country that state control would advantage.

The Founding Fathers clearly did not intend for the states to have governing authority over all matters. Read your history.
Washington, Hamilton, Adams knew that without a federation, a loose confederation of states would not survive. Only the southern states resisted, and they have tried to secede ever since.

As for the South, it did, in effect, secede, and stayed there right put through the likes of George Wallace and even to today in one Jeff "Secessions".
Trump meanwhile has chosen to "secede" from truth-telling...or, maybe, he's never practiced that simple moral value himself (I'm still trying to figure out which moral values he does practice).
